Alternating SQP Method for Optimizing Topic Models and Non-negative Matrix Factorizations

Source: R/altsqp.R
altsqp.Rd

Compute maximum-likelihood estimates for the Poisson topic model with factors F and loadings L; equivalently, find a non-negative matrix factorization \(L * F^T\) of matrix X that optimizes the "generalized Kullback-Leibler" (or Bregman) divergence objective.

altsqp(X, fit, numiter = 100, version = c("Rcpp", "R"),
  control = list(), verbose = TRUE)

altsqp_control_default()

Arguments

X

The n x m matrix of counts or pseudocounts. It can be a dense matrix or sparse matrix.
fit

A list containing two (dense, non-negative) matrices, fit$F and fit$L; for example, this can be the output of altsqp. The former is an m x k matrix of factors (or "basic vectors"), and the latter is an n x k matrix of loadings (or "activations"). For loglik.multinom, it is additionally required that each row of fit$L and each column of fit$F must sum to 1; poisson2multinom can be used to generate factors and loadings satisfying this requirement. For altsqp, this provides the initial estimates.
numiter

A positive integer specifying the number of updates to perform.
version

With version = "R", a slower, but more easily debugged, implementation is used; with version = "Rcpp", a faster, less easily debugged implementation is used.
control

A list of parameters controlling the behaviour of the optimization algorithm. See ‘Details’.
verbose

If verbose = TRUE, the algorithm's progress and a summary of the optimization settings are printed to the console.
e

A small, non-negative number that is added to the terms inside the logarithms to sidestep computing logarithms of zero. This prevents numerical problems at the cost of introducing a small (and typically very small) inaccuracy in the computation.

Value

altsqp returns a list object with the following elements:

F

A dense matrix containing estimates of the factors.

L

A dense matrix containing estimates of the loadings.

value

The value of the objective (or cost function) at the outputted values of F and L. The objective function is equal to -loglik.poisson(X,out$,out$L), where out is the altsqp return value.

progress

A data frame containing more detailed information about the algorithm's progress. The data frame should have numiter rows. The columns of the data frame are: "iter", the SQP iteration; "objective", the value of the objective at the current estimate of the solution; "max.diff", the maximum difference in the Poisson rate parameters tcrossprod(L,F) between two the successive iterations; "beta", the current setting of the extrapolation parameter (zero means no extrapolation is used); and "timing", the elapsed time in seconds (based on system.time).

poisson2multinom returns an updated fit, in which the factors fit$F and loadings fit$L are converted to matrices of the same dimension containing, respectively, word probabilities and topic probabilities.
F

A dense matrix containing estimates of the factors.

L

A dense matrix containing estimates of the loadings.

loglik.poisson and loglik.multinom return a single numeric value giving the value of the log-likelihood.

Details

Functions loglik.poisson and loglik.multinom compute the log-likelihood for the Poisson and multinomial topic models, excluding terms that do not depend on the model parameters. These functions can be used to evaluate a solution returned by altsqp.

Use function poisson2multinom to obtain parameters for the multinomial topic model from the Poisson topic model.

The control argument to altsqp is a list in which any of the following named components will override the default optimization algorithm settings (as they are defined by altsqp_control_default):

nc

When version = "Rcpp", this setting determines the numThreads argument in the call to setThreadOptions. When version = "R", this setting determines the mc.cores argument in calls to mclapply.

numem

A non-negative number specifying the number of EM (i.e., multiplicative) updates to run at each outer loop iteration.

numsqp

A non-negative number specifying the number of SQP updates to run at each outer loop iteration.

extrapolate

The iteration at which extrapolation is initiated. If extrapolate > numiter, extrapolation is not used.

beta.init

The initial setting of the extrapolation parameter.

beta.increase

The extrapolation parameter is increased by this amount whenever the update improves the solution. This is denoted by \(\gamma\) in Algorithm 3 of Ang & Gillis (2019).

beta.reduce

The extrapolation parameter is decreased by this amount whenever the update does not improve the solution. This is denoted by \(\eta\) in Algorithm 3 of Ang & Gillis (2019).

betamax.increase

The upper bound on the extrapolation parameter is increased by this amount whenever the update improves the solution. This is denoted by \(\bar{\gamma}\) in Algorithm 3 of Ang & Gillis (2019).

tol

A small, non-negative number specifying the convergence tolerance for the active-set step. Smaller values will result in higher quality search directions for the SQP algorithm but possibly a greater per-iteration computational cost.

zero.threshold

A small, non-negative number used to determine the "active set"; that is, it determines which entries of the solution are exactly zero. Any entries that are less than or equal to zero.threshold are considered to be exactly zero. Larger values of zero.threshold may lead to speedups for matrices with many columns, at the (slight) risk of prematurely zeroing some co-ordinates.

zero.searchdir

A small, non-negative number used to determine when the search direction in the active-set step is considered "small enough".

suffdecr

This parameter determines how stringent the "sufficient decrease" condition is for accepting a step size in the backtracking line search. Larger values will make the condition more stringent. This should be a positive number less than 1.

stepsizereduce

The multiplicative factor for decreasing the step size in the backtracking line search.

minstepsize

The smallest step size accepted by the line search step. Should be a number greater than 0 and at most 1.

e

The same as input argument e described above.

References

A. Ang and N. Gillis (2019). Accelerating nonnegative matrix factorization algorithms using extrapolation. Neural Computation 31, 417-–439. https://doi.org/10.1162/neco_a_01157

Examples


library(Matrix)
library(NNLM)

# Generate a 300 x 400 data matrix to factorize. Less than 10% of the
# matrix elements should be nonzero.
set.seed(1)
n <- 300
m <- 400
k <- 3
F <- matrix(runif(m*k)/3,m,k)
L <- matrix(runif(n*k)/3,n,k)
X <- matrix(rpois(n*m,tcrossprod(L,F)),n,m)
X <- as(X,"dgCMatrix")
nnzero(X)/(n*m)
#> [1] 0.07648333

# Generate random initial estimates of the factors and loadings.
fit0 <- list(F = matrix(runif(m*k),m,k),
             L = matrix(runif(n*k),n,k))

# Run 100 iterations of the sequential coordinate-wise descent
# algorithm implemented in the NNLM package. Note that nnmf does not
# accept a sparse matrix as input, so we need to provide it with a
# dense matrix instead.
fit1 <- suppressWarnings(
  nnmf(as.matrix(X),k,init = list(W = fit0$L,H = t(fit0$F)),
       method = "scd",loss = "mkl",max.iter = 100,rel.tol = 0,
       inner.max.iter = 4,trace = 1,verbose = 0))

# Run 100 coordinate-wise updates of the SQP method implemented in
# the fastTopics package.
fit2 <- altsqp(X,fit0,verbose = FALSE)
#> Warning: the condition has length > 1 and only the first element will be used
#> Error in progress[iter, "objective"] <- fbest: number of items to replace is not a multiple of replacement length

# Compare the Poisson log-likelihood at the two solutions; the
# likelihood should be higher at the the altsqp solution.
fit1$F <- t(fit1$H)
fit1$L <- fit1$W
print(loglik.poisson(X,fit1),digits = 14)
#> Error in loglik.poisson(X, fit1): could not find function "loglik.poisson"
print(loglik.poisson(X,fit2),digits = 14)
#> Error in loglik.poisson(X, fit2): could not find function "loglik.poisson"

# Compare the multinomial log-likelihood at the two solutions; again,
# the likelihood should be higher at the altsqp solution.
print(loglik.multinom(X,poisson2multinom(fit1)),digits = 14)
#> Error in loglik.multinom(X, poisson2multinom(fit1)): could not find function "loglik.multinom"
print(loglik.multinom(X,poisson2multinom(fit2)),digits = 14)
#> Error in loglik.multinom(X, poisson2multinom(fit2)): could not find function "loglik.multinom"

# Plot the improvement in the solution over time; the altsqp iterates
# (the solid, orange line) gets much closer to the best solution.
fbest    <- 31041.93896745
fit1$mkl <- n*m*fit1$mkl + sum(X - X*log(X + 1e-16))
plot(fit2$progress$iter,fit2$progress$objective - fbest,
     log = "y",col = "darkorange",type = "l",lwd = 2,xlab = "iteration",
     ylab = "distance from solution")
#> Error in plot(fit2$progress$iter, fit2$progress$objective - fbest, log = "y",     col = "darkorange", type = "l", lwd = 2, xlab = "iteration",     ylab = "distance from solution"): object 'fit2' not found
lines(1:60,fit1$mkl - fbest,col = "darkblue",lwd = 2,lty = "dashed")
#> Error in xy.coords(x, y): 'x' and 'y' lengths differ
